title: Cell in std::cell - Rust
markdown:
# Cell in std::cell - Rust

## Struct [std](../index.html)::[cell](index.html)::[Cell](#)

1.0.0 ยท [source](https://doc.rust-lang.org/1.80.0/src/core/cell.rs.html#308) ยท

```
pub struct Cell<T>where
    T: ?Sized,{ /* private fields */ }
```

Expand description

A mutable memory location.

## [ยง](#memory-layout)Memory layout

`Cell<T>` has the same [memory layout and caveats as `UnsafeCell<T>`](about:blank/struct.UnsafeCell.html#memory-layout "struct std::cell::UnsafeCell"). In particular, this means that `Cell<T>` has the same in-memory representation as its inner type `T`.

## [ยง](#examples)Examples

In this example, you can see that `Cell<T>` enables mutation inside an immutable struct. In other words, it enables โinterior mutabilityโ.

```
use std::cell::Cell;

struct SomeStruct {
    regular_field: u8,
    special_field: Cell<u8>,
}

let my_struct = SomeStruct {
    regular_field: 0,
    special_field: Cell::new(1),
};

let new_value = 100;

// ERROR: `my_struct` is immutable
// my_struct.regular_field = new_value;

// WORKS: although `my_struct` is immutable, `special_field` is a `Cell`,
// which can always be mutated
my_struct.special_field.set(new_value);
assert_eq!(my_struct.special_field.get(), new_value);
```

[Run](https://play.rust-lang.org/?code=%23!%5Ballow(unused)%5D%0Afn+main()+%7B%0A++++use+std::cell::Cell;%0A++++%0A++++struct+SomeStruct+%7B%0A++++++++regular_field:+u8,%0A++++++++special_field:+Cell%3Cu8%3E,%0A++++%7D%0A++++%0A++++let+my_struct+=+SomeStruct+%7B%0A++++++++regular_field:+0,%0A++++++++special_field:+Cell::new(1),%0A++++%7D;%0A++++%0A++++let+new_value+=+100;%0A++++%0A++++//+ERROR:+%60my_struct%60+is+immutable%0A++++//+my_struct.regular_field+=+new_value;%0A++++%0A++++//+WORKS:+although+%60my_struct%60+is+immutable,+%60special_field%60+is+a+%60Cell%60,%0A++++//+which+can+always+be+mutated%0A++++my_struct.special_field.set(new_value);%0A++++assert_eq!(my_struct.special_field.get(),+new_value);%0A%7D&edition=2021)

See the [module-level documentation](index.html "mod std::cell") for more.

[source](https://doc.rust-lang.org/1.80.0/src/core/cell.rs.html#395)[ยง](#impl-Cell%3CT%3E)

1.0.0 (const: 1.24.0) ยท [source](https://doc.rust-lang.org/1.80.0/src/core/cell.rs.html#408)

Creates a new `Cell` containing the given value.

##### [ยง](#examples-1)Examples

```
use std::cell::Cell;

let c = Cell::new(5);
```

[Run](https://play.rust-lang.org/?code=%23!%5Ballow(unused)%5D%0Afn+main()+%7B%0A++++use+std::cell::Cell;%0A++++%0A++++let+c+=+Cell::new(5);%0A%7D&edition=2021)

1.0.0 ยท [source](https://doc.rust-lang.org/1.80.0/src/core/cell.rs.html#425)

Sets the contained value.

##### [ยง](#examples-2)Examples

```
use std::cell::Cell;

let c = Cell::new(5);

c.set(10);
```

[Run](https://play.rust-lang.org/?code=%23!%5Ballow(unused)%5D%0Afn+main()+%7B%0A++++use+std::cell::Cell;%0A++++%0A++++let+c+=+Cell::new(5);%0A++++%0A++++c.set(10);%0A%7D&edition=2021)

1.17.0 ยท [source](https://doc.rust-lang.org/1.80.0/src/core/cell.rs.html#451)

Swaps the values of two `Cell`s. Difference with `std::mem::swap` is that this function doesnโt require `&mut` reference.

##### [ยง](#panics)Panics

This function will panic if `self` and `other` are different `Cell`s that partially overlap. (Using just standard library methods, it is impossible to create such partially overlapping `Cell`s. However, unsafe code is allowed to e.g. create two `&Cell<[i32; 2]>` that partially overlap.)

##### [ยง](#examples-3)Examples

```
use std::cell::Cell;

let c1 = Cell::new(5i32);
let c2 = Cell::new(10i32);
c1.swap(&c2);
assert_eq!(10, c1.get());
assert_eq!(5, c2.get());
```

[Run](https://play.rust-lang.org/?code=%23!%5Ballow(unused)%5D%0Afn+main()+%7B%0A++++use+std::cell::Cell;%0A++++%0A++++let+c1+=+Cell::new(5i32);%0A++++let+c2+=+Cell::new(10i32);%0A++++c1.swap(%26c2);%0A++++assert_eq!(10,+c1.get());%0A++++assert_eq!(5,+c2.get());%0A%7D&edition=2021)

1.17.0 ยท [source](https://doc.rust-lang.org/1.80.0/src/core/cell.rs.html#494)

Replaces the contained value with `val`, and returns the old contained value.

##### [ยง](#examples-4)Examples

```
use std::cell::Cell;

let cell = Cell::new(5);
assert_eq!(cell.get(), 5);
assert_eq!(cell.replace(10), 5);
assert_eq!(cell.get(), 10);
```

[Run](https://play.rust-lang.org/?code=%23!%5Ballow(unused)%5D%0Afn+main()+%7B%0A++++use+std::cell::Cell;%0A++++%0A++++let+cell+=+Cell::new(5);%0A++++assert_eq!(cell.get(),+5);%0A++++assert_eq!(cell.replace(10),+5);%0A++++assert_eq!(cell.get(),+10);%0A%7D&edition=2021)

1.17.0 (const: [unstable](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/78729 "Tracking issue for const_cell_into_inner")) ยท [source](https://doc.rust-lang.org/1.80.0/src/core/cell.rs.html#514)

Unwraps the value, consuming the cell.

##### [ยง](#examples-5)Examples

```
use std::cell::Cell;

let c = Cell::new(5);
let five = c.into_inner();

assert_eq!(five, 5);
```

[Run](https://play.rust-lang.org/?code=%23!%5Ballow(unused)%5D%0Afn+main()+%7B%0A++++use+std::cell::Cell;%0A++++%0A++++let+c+=+Cell::new(5);%0A++++let+five+=+c.into_inner();%0A++++%0A++++assert_eq!(five,+5);%0A%7D&edition=2021)

[source](https://doc.rust-lang.org/1.80.0/src/core/cell.rs.html#519)[ยง](#impl-Cell%3CT%3E-1)

1.0.0 ยท [source](https://doc.rust-lang.org/1.80.0/src/core/cell.rs.html#533)

Returns a copy of the contained value.

##### [ยง](#examples-6)Examples

```
use std::cell::Cell;

let c = Cell::new(5);

let five = c.get();
```

[Run](https://play.rust-lang.org/?code=%23!%5Ballow(unused)%5D%0Afn+main()+%7B%0A++++use+std::cell::Cell;%0A++++%0A++++let+c+=+Cell::new(5);%0A++++%0A++++let+five+=+c.get();%0A%7D&edition=2021)

[source](https://doc.rust-lang.org/1.80.0/src/core/cell.rs.html#556-558)

๐ฌThis is a nightly-only experimental API. (`cell_update`ย[#50186](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/50186))

Updates the contained value using a function and returns the new value.

##### [ยง](#examples-7)Examples

```
#![feature(cell_update)]

use std::cell::Cell;

let c = Cell::new(5);
let new = c.update(|x| x + 1);

assert_eq!(new, 6);
assert_eq!(c.get(), 6);
```

[Run](https://play.rust-lang.org/?code=%23!%5Ballow(unused)%5D%0A%23!%5Bfeature(cell_update)%5D%0A%0Afn+main()+%7B%0A++++use+std::cell::Cell;%0A++++%0A++++let+c+=+Cell::new(5);%0A++++let+new+=+c.update(%7Cx%7C+x+%2B+1);%0A++++%0A++++assert_eq!(new,+6);%0A++++assert_eq!(c.get(),+6);%0A%7D&version=nightly&edition=2021)

[source](https://doc.rust-lang.org/1.80.0/src/core/cell.rs.html#567)[ยง](#impl-Cell%3CT%3E-2)

1.12.0 (const: 1.32.0) ยท [source](https://doc.rust-lang.org/1.80.0/src/core/cell.rs.html#583)

Returns a raw pointer to the underlying data in this cell.

##### [ยง](#examples-8)Examples

```
use std::cell::Cell;

let c = Cell::new(5);

let ptr = c.as_ptr();
```

[Run](https://play.rust-lang.org/?code=%23!%5Ballow(unused)%5D%0Afn+main()+%7B%0A++++use+std::cell::Cell;%0A++++%0A++++let+c+=+Cell::new(5);%0A++++%0A++++let+ptr+=+c.as_ptr();%0A%7D&edition=2021)

1.11.0 ยท [source](https://doc.rust-lang.org/1.80.0/src/core/cell.rs.html#611)

Returns a mutable reference to the underlying data.

This call borrows `Cell` mutably (at compile-time) which guarantees that we possess the only reference.

However be cautious: this method expects `self` to be mutable, which is generally not the case when using a `Cell`. If you require interior mutability by reference, consider using `RefCell` which provides run-time checked mutable borrows through its [`borrow_mut`](about:blank/struct.RefCell.html#method.borrow_mut "method std::cell::RefCell::borrow_mut") method.

##### [ยง](#examples-9)Examples

```
use std::cell::Cell;

let mut c = Cell::new(5);
*c.get_mut() += 1;

assert_eq!(c.get(), 6);
```

[Run](https://play.rust-lang.org/?code=%23!%5Ballow(unused)%5D%0Afn+main()+%7B%0A++++use+std::cell::Cell;%0A++++%0A++++let+mut+c+=+Cell::new(5);%0A++++*c.get_mut()+%2B=+1;%0A++++%0A++++assert_eq!(c.get(),+6);%0A%7D&edition=2021)

1.37.0 ยท [source](https://doc.rust-lang.org/1.80.0/src/core/cell.rs.html#630)

Returns a `&Cell<T>` from a `&mut T`

##### [ยง](#examples-10)Examples

```
use std::cell::Cell;

let slice: &mut [i32] = &mut [1, 2, 3];
let cell_slice: &Cell<[i32]> = Cell::from_mut(slice);
let slice_cell: &[Cell<i32>] = cell_slice.as_slice_of_cells();

assert_eq!(slice_cell.len(), 3);
```

[Run](https://play.rust-lang.org/?code=%23!%5Ballow(unused)%5D%0Afn+main()+%7B%0A++++use+std::cell::Cell;%0A++++%0A++++let+slice:+%26mut+%5Bi32%5D+=+%26mut+%5B1,+2,+3%5D;%0A++++let+cell_slice:+%26Cell%3C%5Bi32%5D%3E+=+Cell::from_mut(slice);%0A++++let+slice_cell:+%26%5BCell%3Ci32%3E%5D+=+cell_slice.as_slice_of_cells();%0A++++%0A++++assert_eq!(slice_cell.len(),+3);%0A%7D&edition=2021)

[source](https://doc.rust-lang.org/1.80.0/src/core/cell.rs.html#636)[ยง](#impl-Cell%3CT%3E-3)

1.17.0 ยท [source](https://doc.rust-lang.org/1.80.0/src/core/cell.rs.html#651)

Takes the value of the cell, leaving `Default::default()` in its place.

##### [ยง](#examples-11)Examples

```
use std::cell::Cell;

let c = Cell::new(5);
let five = c.take();

assert_eq!(five, 5);
assert_eq!(c.into_inner(), 0);
```

[Run](https://play.rust-lang.org/?code=%23!%5Ballow(unused)%5D%0Afn+main()+%7B%0A++++use+std::cell::Cell;%0A++++%0A++++let+c+=+Cell::new(5);%0A++++let+five+=+c.take();%0A++++%0A++++assert_eq!(five,+5);%0A++++assert_eq!(c.into_inner(),+0);%0A%7D&edition=2021)

[source](https://doc.rust-lang.org/1.80.0/src/core/cell.rs.html#669)[ยง](#impl-Cell%3C%5BT%5D%3E)

Returns a `&[Cell<T>]` from a `&Cell<[T]>`

##### [ยง](#examples-12)Examples

```
use std::cell::Cell;

let slice: &mut [i32] = &mut [1, 2, 3];
let cell_slice: &Cell<[i32]> = Cell::from_mut(slice);
let slice_cell: &[Cell<i32>] = cell_slice.as_slice_of_cells();

assert_eq!(slice_cell.len(), 3);
```

[Run](https://play.rust-lang.org/?code=%23!%5Ballow(unused)%5D%0Afn+main()+%7B%0A++++use+std::cell::Cell;%0A++++%0A++++let+slice:+%26mut+%5Bi32%5D+=+%26mut+%5B1,+2,+3%5D;%0A++++let+cell_slice:+%26Cell%3C%5Bi32%5D%3E+=+Cell::from_mut(slice);%0A++++let+slice_cell:+%26%5BCell%3Ci32%3E%5D+=+cell_slice.as_slice_of_cells();%0A++++%0A++++assert_eq!(slice_cell.len(),+3);%0A%7D&edition=2021)

[source](https://doc.rust-lang.org/1.80.0/src/core/cell.rs.html#690)[ยง](#impl-Cell%3C%5BT;+N%5D%3E)

[source](https://doc.rust-lang.org/1.80.0/src/core/cell.rs.html#704)

๐ฌThis is a nightly-only experimental API. (`as_array_of_cells`ย[#88248](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/88248))

Returns a `&[Cell<T>; N]` from a `&Cell<[T; N]>`

##### [ยง](#examples-13)Examples

```
#![feature(as_array_of_cells)]
use std::cell::Cell;

let mut array: [i32; 3] = [1, 2, 3];
let cell_array: &Cell<[i32; 3]> = Cell::from_mut(&mut array);
let array_cell: &[Cell<i32>; 3] = cell_array.as_array_of_cells();
```

[Run](https://play.rust-lang.org/?code=%23!%5Ballow(unused)%5D%0A%23!%5Bfeature(as_array_of_cells)%5D%0Afn+main()+%7B%0A++++use+std::cell::Cell;%0A++++%0A++++let+mut+array:+%5Bi32;+3%5D+=+%5B1,+2,+3%5D;%0A++++let+cell_array:+%26Cell%3C%5Bi32;+3%5D%3E+=+Cell::from_mut(%26mut+array);%0A++++let+array_cell:+%26%5BCell%3Ci32%3E;+3%5D+=+cell_array.as_array_of_cells();%0A%7D&version=nightly&edition=2021)

Struct std::cell::Cell

1.0.0 ยท source ยท 
pub struct Cell<T>
where
    T: ?Sized,
{ /* private fields */ }
Expand description

A mutable memory location.

ยงMemory layout

Cell<T> has the same memory layout and caveats as UnsafeCell<T>. In particular, this means that Cell<T> has the same in-memory representation as its inner type T.

ยงExamples

In this example, you can see that Cell<T> enables mutation inside an immutable struct. In other words, it enables โinterior mutabilityโ.

use std::cell::Cell;

struct SomeStruct {
    regular_field: u8,
    special_field: Cell<u8>,
}

let my_struct = SomeStruct {
    regular_field: 0,
    special_field: Cell::new(1),
};

let new_value = 100;

// ERROR: `my_struct` is immutable
// my_struct.regular_field = new_value;

// WORKS: although `my_struct` is immutable, `special_field` is a `Cell`,
// which can always be mutated
my_struct.special_field.set(new_value);
assert_eq!(my_struct.special_field.get(), new_value);
Run

See the module-level documentation for more.

1.17.0 ยท source

pub fn swap(&self, other: &Cell<T>)

Swaps the values of two Cells. Difference with std::mem::swap is that this function doesnโt require &mut reference.

ยงPanics

This function will panic if self and other are different Cells that partially overlap. (Using just standard library methods, it is impossible to create such partially overlapping Cells. However, unsafe code is allowed to e.g. create two &Cell<[i32; 2]> that partially overlap.)

ยงExamples
use std::cell::Cell;

let c1 = Cell::new(5i32);
let c2 = Cell::new(10i32);
c1.swap(&c2);
assert_eq!(10, c1.get());
assert_eq!(5, c2.get());
Run
1.17.0 ยท source

pub fn replace(&self, val: T) -> T

Replaces the contained value with val, and returns the old contained value.

ยงExamples
use std::cell::Cell;

let cell = Cell::new(5);
assert_eq!(cell.get(), 5);
assert_eq!(cell.replace(10), 5);
assert_eq!(cell.get(), 10);
Run

1.11.0 ยท source

pub fn get_mut(&mut self) -> &mut T

Returns a mutable reference to the underlying data.

This call borrows Cell mutably (at compile-time) which guarantees that we possess the only reference.

However be cautious: this method expects self to be mutable, which is generally not the case when using a Cell. If you require interior mutability by reference, consider using RefCell which provides run-time checked mutable borrows through its borrow_mut method.

ยงExamples
use std::cell::Cell;

let mut c = Cell::new(5);
*c.get_mut() += 1;

assert_eq!(c.get(), 6);
Run
1.37.0 ยท source

Returns a &Cell<T> from a &mut T

ยงExamples

let slice: &mut [i32] = &mut [1, 2, 3];
let cell_slice: &Cell<[i32]> = Cell::from_mut(slice);
let slice_cell: &[Cell<i32>] = cell_slice.as_slice_of_cells();
